div1.p: Hench discusses various meetings he had in Cuba to acquire biographical information.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, May 7, 1940
div1.opener:
MAYO CLINIC
ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA
May 7, 1940
DR. PHILIP S. HENCH
DR. CHARLES H. SLOCUMB
General J. R. Kean
2804 N Street N. W.
Georgetown
Washington, D. C.
My dear General Kean:
div1.p:
I had a delightful and most interesting experience with Mr. Moran for ten
days in Havana last month. It is a long story which I hope to tell you in person,
if possible within the next few weeks. There are many angles of the story of which
I was not aware, some of them most inspiring and some of them, as you know, not too
inspiring. I had conversations with Dr. Agramonte's daughter, Dr. Albertini,
others of the Finlay Institute, etc. etc. Most important of all, I found that the
Cuban government had picked the wrong site of Camp Lazear and already had a temporary
memorial up, and were planning a series of memorial buildings. I soon found that
they had made a mistake, and spent some time searching for the real site of the camp.
We discovered it, and then I had to get documentary evidence to support our claims.
I think we convinced the authorities, at least in part. They have asked me to submit
a report, and they will appoint a commission to review the matter. This is all
aside from my interest in the history of the yellow fever experiments.

Mr. Moran told me that he had presented a second edition of Kelly's book
to the University of Virginia library, and Mr. Harry Clemons, librarian, has graciously
loaned me this book. Mr. Clemons tells me there is also a very interesting, long
letter from you there and that he would be willing to send me photoprint copies of
your letter if I have your permission. I should appreciate this courtesy very much
indeed, and if you would either write me or Mr. Clemons, I should certainly be glad.

If it is entirely convenient for you, I plan to stop in Washington to call
upon you about June 14 or 15. I should like to give you a brief outline of what
I have found and to ask you certain questions, perhaps even impose upon your graciousness
to have you consult your diary or let me see it regarding the pertinent details of
the yellow fever work. I am getting quite a lot of interesting material which I
hope to present before the Washington and Jefferson College in October, at the time
they dedicate the new Lazear Building. Lazear was a Washington and Jefferson man
before he went to Hopkins. I shall also plan to publish this in some medical historical
journal. This is aside from the stories by Moran and Kissinger themselves which I
hope to get published under their own names.

I cannot tell you how much Mr. Moran and I appreciate your offer of help
in this matter.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
